title: Can someone truly have the 'wrong' opinion? - Quora

response.answer_text: LOL what a funny question. Yes of course. Some things in life are factual and some things are not. For example, if someone’s opinion that 2+2=5, they would be wrong. However, most everything is not as deductive as mathematics. For example, if we ask “is it hot or cold outside?”. Well, we can objectively say that the temperature is 70 degrees Fahrenheit. But the observer is what matters here, less so the external world. So one person’s hot might be another person’s cold. I might say, it’s 70 degrees outside and I am cold, and another person would say it’s 70 degrees outside and I feel hot. Both are mostly true. As human beings in the universe, everything is perception, and most “truths” about the world are simply not independent of our observation. Most people that work in science and engineering realize that there are cold hard truths about the world that are very true no matter what you do. But there are a lot of people on Earth that operate differently and have trouble accepting or recognizing universal truths or objective fact. Those people are bad, LOL.

If you mean having an opinion on something that has a right or wrong answer, then you're wrong simply by having an opinion, rather than knowing what the answer actually is. You should never have opinions about things that aren't subjective.But if it's a subjective things, then no, it's impossible to have the wrong opinion. You can never be wrong about something that is subjective, because if so then it is objective, not subjective. Subjective things are things that depend on a mind. Therefore, the mind is in charge of it, aswell, so it cannot be wrong. "Right or wrong" doesn't even make sense in that context. Objective things, however, do not depend on minds, and minds do not change them. So if the mind is not in line with that thing, then the mind is wrong about it. If you cannot or do not know what is right about it, there is no point in having an "opinion" about it, since that would be to treat it as if it was subjective when it isn't.

Yes. Now an opinion is a tricky thing to define, but quite simply it's a judgement on something using one's own knowledge. If one is ignorant on something, an opinion could be wrong. For example, if I believed that Disneyworld was in California, and said that it should be moved to South Dakota because California is not good enough for it, part of that opinion is wrong. However, one who is mentally ill may have a wrong opinion due to their condition. One might think that a man named Guy Fieri is the president of the US and was on the ballot. This obviously isn't true, as there wasn't a candidate called Guy Fieri on the ballot in any of the 50 states.

It is my opinion that, yes people can truly have the “wrong” opinion, and I can prove that this opinion must be correct. Here’s a simple proof: Now that I have stated my opinion, you must either agree with me, disagree with me, or remain undecided. If you agree then we are in agreement, people can have the “wrong” opinion. However, if you disagree with me, you actually prove me correct by believing that my opinion is wrong. Even if you remain undecided, you prove that my opinion is correct because you are acknowledging the possibility that my opinion might be wrong, which of course is only possible if it can be wrong. So the question is decisively answered: Yes, of course they can.

Well…somebody can surely offer an opinion that is in fact wrong in view of the true and verifiable facts regarding the issue at hand. BUT…there is a caveat here that all the responders to this question failed to understand. Including that “software engineer” guy. LOL> And that is: a person cannot be “lying” ot “telling a false or wrong statement” IF they preface their words by saying: “This is my opinion.” That is to say…even if the opinion of the person is not congruent with the objective facts on the matter, well, it is still only his opinion he is offering. Now…if he says…..”Trump is clinically retarded” then you can deem his claim wrong, as it will not stand-up in a medical, objective, psychiatric test. But if you just say “I think he acts retarded at times” then NO—-what you say IS the truth, since you are only offering what you think. That is, your own opinion. Hope this helps. Cheers.

There's an old saying that “Opinions are like assholes; everyone has one, and they all stink.” I do think that you can have a wrong opinion, if it was founded on faulty premises. For instance, some people hate gay men because they think they're all pedophiles. Of course, not even most gay men are pedophiles, and most pedophiles are straight men, often married, even. So that would be a faulty opinion, in my opinion. But we all know what opinions are worth.

I see several answers which state that opinions are meaningless if they are not backed up by facts. To those who so believe let me ask these two questions, and please provide answers which are supported by facts and not opinions: Is rape ever a beautiful thing?Is torturing children for fun OK?You see, all of us know these things are wrong, but without an absolute standard against which we can judge something all we can ever have are preferences and opinions. I would prefer that we not torture children for any reason, but without an absolute moral standard I cannot say it is wrong. No one reading this would say that there are times when rape is beautiful (at least I hope not), so someone holding such an opinion would be said to be wrong without any facts to back them up.

An opinion is “a belief or idea held with confidence, but not substantiated by direct proof or knowledge, a common, usual, or prevailing view or sentiment”. Any opinion can have some odd basis in fact , but no opinion can have any verifiable evidence to support a belief. An opinion, taken with a grain of salt , will only raise your blood pressure, but never approach the proof necessary for logicaal evidence.

No, because opinion is defined as the “view or judgment formed about something, not necessarily based on fact or knowledge”. An opinion is based on a person’s point of view and previous knowledge, and since we all have had different experiences, our opinions could be different or similar. It all depends on a person’s belief and judgement.

There is no wrong opinion. A quick Google search of the word opinion defines it as "a view or judgment formed about something, not necessarily based on fact or knowledge." Opinions are the lenses through which you view the world, and are largely shaped by various factors within your immediate environment and the experiences you go through. Therefore, it differs widely across people and the drifts are even larger among people who are in different environments who do not share common experiences. It is unfortunate that most conflicts often arise when certain segments or people feel their opinions are "more correct" than others.

It depends on how you state your opinion. If you state it as fact then it could be wrong. For example, if I say, “The Earth is flat.” then, even though it might just be my opinion, the way it was delivered allows others to accept or disclaim it. On the other hand, if presented properly as an opinion, I might say “I believe the Earth is flat.” Then the statement is about what I believe and I am am the only one who knows whether I lied about what I believe. Believing that the Earth is flat has nothing to do with whether or not it is flat.

No, I believe whatever opinions people make are because of their upbringing and how much they bringed themselves up. So its not actually anybody's fault. But two people no need to like each other's opinions necessarily xD

I have often wondered about that question. How can my opinion be wrong if it is just my opinion? I kind of understand that if I said, in my opinion, the world is flat, I would be making an incorrect statement. Does that, however; make my opinion wrong? If an opinion is an idea, it can be wrong. If an opinion is just a thought, I don’t see how a thought in that sense can be wrong.
Yes. People can be of the opinion that the Earth is flat, or that the moon landings were faked. Both opinions are clearly wrong.
No. As to the others, they can.
